column2: H. H.|AGU Fall Meeting Abstracts|2013||P54B-05|Synthesis of Is/FeO maturity indexes for Apollo 17 regolith samples in the valley of Taurus-Littrow on the Moon indicate that high levels of ilmenite in the samples significantly reduces the level of this indicator of space exposure. The analysis
column3: along with consideration of regolith glass characteristics
column4: also discloses that micro-meteor fluxes vary over geologic time
column5: presumably in response to significant impact events in the Asteroid Belt. Surface samples of ilmenite-poor
column6: silicate-rich regolith have about 80-90% higher maturity indexes than surface samples of ilmenite-rich
column7: basaltic regolith of comparable exposure. For comparison of the history of various regolith exposures to the space environment
column9: the youngest large area stratigraphic unit
column10: provides a specific time horizon. For at least the last ~110 million years
column11: the currently estimated age of the light mantle avalanche
column12: most near surface (upper 1-5cm) regolith has had approximately the same exposure to micro-meteors. The surface of the largely ilmenite-rich basalt fill in the valley has been exposed to space at least as long or possibly 30 million years longer than the light mantle
column13: based on exposure ages for large boulder ejecta in the Camelot cluster of craters. High apparent maturity (Is/FeO >80)
column15: exists only on three types of regolith surfaces: (1) the North Massif apron (e.g.
column20: 72150). Only intermediate to low maturity (Is/FeO <60) has developed in surface regolith overlying high titanium basalt (e.g.
column21: 70181). TiO2/TiO2+FeO ratios provide a good measure of original ilmenite content
column22: ilmenite being the only quantitatively significant titanium-bearing mineral in the regolith. Those ratios for samples showing high and intermediate apparent maturity are about 0.35 and 0.25
column25: 77260) exposed at Shorty Crater as a unit stratigraphically overlying the orange ash
column26: has exceptionally low maturity (8% agglutinates and Is/FeO = 5) but an unusually high amount of "ropy" glass (14-18%). (Ropy glass normally constitutes less than on percent of new Taurus-Littrow regolith. It forms within fresh impact craters as a result of macro-meteor impacts
column27: but the current flux of micro-meteors disaggregates such glass within a million years or less.) The light mantle avalanche deposit protected this ancient regolith unit at Shorty Crater for at up to 90 million years prior to the Shorty impact 14-17 million years ago. A significant micro-meteor flux cannot have existed during the formation of this ancient regolith or it would have a higher maturity index and little or no ropy glass. Variable maturities observed in core samples from elsewhere in the valley of Taurus-Littrow may be the result of either variable mirco-meteor flux or variable exposure during periods of moderate flux or a combination of both.|

column1: 2001E&PSL.186..335S|2001|Measurements of neutron capture effects on Cd
column2: Sm and Gd in lunar samples with implications for the neutron energy spectrum|Sands
column7: K. J. R.|Earth and Planetary Science Letters|186|3-4|335|The bombardment of the lunar surface by cosmic rays produces secondary neutrons
column8: some of which are thermalized by the lunar soil and then interact strongly with the isotopes of Cd
column9: Gd and Sm which have high neutron capture cross sections at thermal energies causing changes in their isotopic compositions. We have measured these changes in samples from the Apollo 14
column10: 16 and 17 missions using thermal ionization mass spectrometry. Changes of <SUP>114</SUP>Cd/<SUP>113</SUP>Cd of 0.3-0.5% in samples 60501
column22: have been observed. This is the first time that neutron capture on Cd has been detected in lunar samples. Thermal neutrons are captured preferentially at resonance energies of 0.03 eV by <SUP>155</SUP>Gd and <SUP>157</SUP>Gd
column23: at 0.09 eV by <SUP>149</SUP>Sm and at 0.178 eV by <SUP>113</SUP>Cd. A comparison of the changes in <SUP>114</SUP>Cd/<SUP>113</SUP>Cd
column25: <SUP>158</SUP>Gd/<SUP>157</SUP>Gd and <SUP>150</SUP>Sm/<SUP>149</SUP>Sm due to neutron capture can therefore indicate the energy distribution of the neutrons. Previous work has compared changes in <SUP>158</SUP>Gd/<SUP>157</SUP>Gd and <SUP>150</SUP>Sm/<SUP>149</SUP>Sm
column26: while this study extends the comparison to <SUP>114</SUP>Cd/<SUP>113</SUP>Cd
column27: where the resonance energy is significantly higher. This has enabled us to confirm evidence for a harder neutron energy spectrum in lunar soil than is predicted theoretically. This can be seen in significantly higher capture rates than predicted for <SUP>149</SUP>Sm compared to <SUP>157</SUP>Gd. We also present evidence of enhanced capture rates on <SUP>113</SUP>Cd compared with <SUP>149</SUP>Sm and <SUP>157</SUP>Gd. The concentrations of Cd
column28: Gd and Sm in nine lunar samples have also been measured by isotope dilution mass spectrometry with Cd being measured in lunar samples for the first time by this method. While Cd was found to be heterogeneously distributed in some samples
column29: Gd and Sm showed good agreement with previous measurements

column8: and Sample Datasets|||63|The purpose of this paper is to express the average composition of lunar soils at Apollo landing sites in terms of four principal mineral groups
column12: olivine and opaque (mostly ilmenite) Several studies have shown that lunar soil predominantly consists of lithic fragments of mare and highland rocks
column15: and the single grains of minerals. To achieve this goal
column16: we have compiled modal data from the literature and recast them in terms of these minerals. The distribution of percentages for the lithic and mineral components of the lunar soil samples (90-150 pm) was compiled from the modal data in the Handbook of Lunar Soils and checked against primary sources. We used our own analyses for soils 14141
column23: and fused soil was neglected on the assumption that they approximately represented the modal distribution of the minerals in the soil. Grains classified as anorthosites
column26: and highland basalt were grouped as "higuand rocks"; those classified as mare basalt and KREEP basalt were grouped as "mare rocks."|
